commentary.line: That's stumps on Day 2. A day which could have been so much worse for the Kiwis had it not been for those quick wickets towards the fag-end. Atleast, it gives them some hope with both set batsmen back in the hutch. They were rubbed into the dirt by a humongous 289-run partnership for the most part. It began promisingly for the hosts though. Boult utilized the early morning nip on offer to get rid of Khawaja. But what followed was heavily distressing and disheartening. The pitch, where the ball darted around at the same time yesterday, went benign. Completely. Full credit to the pair of Burns and Smith though. The duo completely shut the door and offered very little to no chances. Their record-breaking stand has helped the Aussies to within touching distance of New Zealand's first innings score and even raised hopes of a crushing lead. One that will completely take the game away. A big effort is needed first thing tomorrow and as the cliche goes "The first session is crucial". We'll be back to bring you all the action. See you then..
109.6   Wagner to Lyon, no run, and he's survived. Slippery short of length delivery around chest high, Lyon works it towards mid-on
109.5   Wagner to Lyon, no run, quick one and well directed towards the badge, safely hunches under it
109.4   Wagner to Lyon, no run, oh no. Make him play. Lyon is allowed another let-go with a short ball outside off
109.3   Wagner to Lyon, no run, an easy leave. Good height on the short ball but it's outside off
109.2   Wagner to Lyon, no run, another one banged in halfway, and Lyon decides to fend it off rather than ducking. Bunts it off the sticker into the off-side
109.1   Wagner to Lyon, no run, brisk short ball gunning for the rib-cage from round the wicket, Lyon barely keeps it out in front of short leg off the splice
108.6   Matt Henry to Voges, no run, breathes a sigh of relief after patting a short of length delivery into the off-side. He would hope his job is done for the day. Over to the night-watchman

108.4   Matt Henry to Voges, no run, better length. Fullish just outside off, Voges has to reach out in defence
108.3   Matt Henry to Voges, no run, no problems there. Firm as a rock on the back foot to defend
108.2   Matt Henry to Voges, no run, shuffles across towards off to defend a back of a length delivery
108.1   Matt Henry to Voges, no run, wayward bumper as it's well down leg, Voges squats his knees as a precautionary measure
107.6   Wagner to Lyon, no run, easily defended off the back foot. Got to get him forward
107.5   Wagner to Lyon, no run, angled in towards leg, Lyon is too quick to close the bat-face and his leading edge nearly pops to silly mid-on
107.4   Wagner to Lyon, no run, slips in a bouncer and Lyon rushes to crouch under it
Switches to round the wicket..
107.3   Wagner to Lyon, no run, and again. Excellent awareness of his sticks and the left-armer's angle, lets it pass
107.2   Wagner to Lyon, no run, that's another good leave. Judges the line early and again pulls the bat inside the line
107.1   Wagner to Voges, 1 run, allows Voges to get off strike with a gentle one on the hips, glanced down to fine leg
106.6   Matt Henry to Lyon, no run, keeps it full and straight and Lyon shows he is no mug with the bat with another stout forward block
106.5   Matt Henry to Lyon, no run, prods forward to a full ball and defends into the on-side

106.4   Matt Henry to Lyon, FOUR, excellent delivery. Holds its line from a good length around off, Lyon had to play at it. He is done in by the late movement and gets a thick edge which flies away past the diving gully into the fence
106.3   Matt Henry to Lyon, no run, length ball wide of off, another delivery wasted
106.2   Matt Henry to Lyon, no run, skiddy back of a length delivery which fizzes through to the keeper after being left alone
106.1   Matt Henry to Voges, 1 run, back of a length delivery around off, Voges hopes on the crease and tucks it through square leg
105.6   Wagner to Lyon, no run, moves inches forward to a length delivery and blocks it back
105.5   Wagner to Lyon, no run, swishes his bat inside the line deliberately to leave a length ball outside off
105.4   Wagner to Lyon, no run, Lyon is expecting a bumper and almost crouches instantly as the ball is released from Wagner's hand. Well underneath it
105.3   Wagner to Lyon, no run, gets the line wrong with this bouncer, it's down leg allowing an easy let-go
105.2   Wagner to Lyon, no run, pushed across the night-watchman on a good length, left alone
Nathan Lyon, right handed bat, comes to the crease

105.1   Wagner to Smith, out Caught by Guptill!! You gotta be kidding me! It's like an action replay of Burns's dismissal. That short ball strategy only took 250+ runs to work and it's produced two wickets now. Both set batsmen gone. Smith swivels across and pulls it well but again, it's straight to Guptill at square leg. Window of opportunity for NZ. Smith c Guptill b Wagner 138(241) [4s-17]
Wagner to Smith, THAT'S OUT!! Caught!!
104.6   Matt Henry to Voges, no run, draws him forward with a fullish ball, Voges is prepared to offer some respect in defence
104.5   Matt Henry to Voges, no run, back of a length delivery which holds its line outside off and squares up Voges slightly as he defends
104.4   Matt Henry to Voges, no run, prods forward to a full ball on middle and blocks
104.3   Matt Henry to Smith, 1 run, moves across on the back foot to punch a similar delivery to deep point
104.2   Matt Henry to Smith, no run, hits a back of a length outside off, steered towards point
104.1   Matt Henry to Smith, no run, length ball outside off, left alone
Matt Henry [24.0-5-82-0] is back into the attack
103.6   Wagner to Voges, no run, another short of length delivery which is safely blunted back down the pitch
103.5   Wagner to Voges, no run, falls down the leg-side this time, Voges moves inside the line and leaves

103.4   Wagner to Voges, no run, he's hit him. That's more like it. Vicious short ball on the stumps, and Voges can't get out of the way. He simply stands his ground, turns his head backward while raising his arms in hope. Smacked under the arm-pit
103.3   Wagner to Voges, no run, now Wagner has some added fuel in the tank. Another short one, but will require some more effort to climb on a tall Voges, worked safely wide of short-leg
Adam Voges, right handed bat, comes to the crease

103.2   Wagner to Burns, out Caught by Guptill!! A wicket. After ages. The short ball ploy which looked like a sure-shot brain implosion has come off. Wagner bangs it in and gets much more height on this one. Even so, Burns is able to pull it nicely. Hits it well enough but just that it went straight to square leg where Guptill takes it inches from the turf. Burns c Guptill b Wagner 170(321) [4s-20]
Wagner to Burns, THAT'S OUT!! Caught!!
103.1   Wagner to Burns, FOUR, the field is set for the short ball but Wagner can't get it high enough, the line is on leg-stump to make it easier for Burns as he helps the pull fine
102.6   Williamson to Burns, 1 run, nurdled behind square to procure a single which will help him keep strike
102.5   Williamson to Burns, no run, shimmies down, gets too close to the ball and jams the drive into the pitch towards mid-off

102.3   Williamson to Burns, no run, flatter on middle, tucked to short mid-wicket
102.2   Williamson to Burns, no run, backs away a touch and punches it to short cover
102.1   Williamson to Burns, no run, teased up on off, defended with a forward lunge
101.6   Wagner to Smith, no run, nearly on the walk while whipping a full ball to mid-on
101.5   Wagner to Smith, no run, plonks his front foot across and defends this length ball with bat and pad close
101.4   Wagner to Smith, no run, fraction full outside off and driven to cover
101.3   Wagner to Smith, no run, shuffling a long way across to cover the line of a short of length delivery
101.2   Wagner to Smith, no run, covers the off-stump and lets this length ball through

101.1   Wagner to Smith, FOUR, dabbed away between gully and slip. New Zealand look blank. Don't know what to do right now. Completely at the mercy of this duo. Back of a length delivery just outside off, but it's wide enough for Smith to run it fine with an open bat-face
100.6   Williamson to Burns, no run, skidding on from a length on middle, Burns cautiously keeps it out from the crease
100.5   Williamson to Burns, no run, darted on leg, Burns clips it to square leg
100.4   Williamson to Smith, 1 run, looped up nicely and Smith works it with the turn to mid-on
100.3   Williamson to Burns, 1 run, punched off the back foot to sweeper cover
100.2   Williamson to Smith, 1 run, flatter on the pads, tucked wide of mid-wicket
100.1   Williamson to Burns, 1 run, shortish and sliding away outside off, cut to deep cover
99.6   Wagner to Smith, no run, full outside off, driven to cover
99.5   Wagner to Burns, 3 runs, looks to pull off the front foot again and this time he botches it. Sliced it off the top edge but enough wood on it to clear a chasing mid-on
99.4   Wagner to Burns, no run, short of length delivery around off, fended off into the off-side
Wagner is going very close to that return crease with his back foot. Something to watch out for
99.3   Wagner to Burns, FOUR, pulled off the front foot. Just transferred his weight back on seeing the nothing length and crunched it backward of square
99.2   Wagner to Burns, no run, short of length to Burns from round the wicket, Burns is solid as ever on the back foot

99.1   Wagner to Smith, 1 run, even though Smith has to reach out away from the body, the length is so full that there is minimal risk, drives it wide of cover-point where Boult puts in a diving effort
Neil Wagner [14.0-2-46-0] is back into the attack
98.6   Williamson to Smith, 1 run, whipped to mid-on who is fairly deep allowing a quick single to transpire
98.5   Williamson to Smith, no run, flatter and sliding on from off, defended off the back foot
98.4   Williamson to Smith, no run, drifting across off, no turn, Smith pushes it to cover
98.3   Williamson to Burns, 1 run, too full to trouble him, driven to long-off
98.2   Williamson to Burns, no run, turned towards short mid-wicket
98.1   Williamson to Burns, no run, tossed up on off from round the wicket, Burns presses forward and defends
Kane Williamson [2.0-0-4-0] is back into the attack
97.6   Boult to Smith, no run, punched off the front foot to mid-off
97.5   Boult to Smith, no run, full ball outside off, left alone

97.4   Boult to Smith, FOUR, oh so nearly! Misses off-stump by a whisker. Smith decides to take liberties and looks to dab a length ball fine towards the third man fence, it's not short enough to be playing it. Chops it off a thick inside edge and collects four. Another record has been broken. This is now the highest 3rd wicket partnership for Australia against New Zealand
97.3   Boult to Smith, no run, shuffles across and blocks a back of a length delivery
97.2   Boult to Smith, no run, dishes a full and wide one luring Smith again, this time he middles the drive and finds cover
97.1   Boult to Smith, FOUR, slashes hard at a full ball and it races away off a thick outside edge past a flying gully
96.6   Southee to Burns, no run, full again and driven back down the pitch
96.5   Southee to Burns, no run, length ball on off, defended after getting half-forward
96.4   Southee to Burns, FOUR, how many more? Just too full. Half-volley on middle to Burns who is perched over 150, won't miss out. Punches it straight of mid-on

94.6   Southee to Smith, 1 run, fullish on middle, glanced down to fine leg

94.5   Southee to Smith, no run, fullish and driven to the right of mid-off, and Smith sets off. The fielder is quick to slide across and field resulting in a mix-up but the call for "no" is soon enough to prevent a disaster
94.4   Southee to Smith, FOUR, Smith puts away another half-volley to the fence with a sublime on-drive to bring up the 250 partnership. Them runs keep coming
94.3   Southee to Burns, 1 run, cuts this short ball to deep point and brings up 150. His first in Tests
94.2   Southee to Burns, no run, pushed from the crease towards cover
94.1   Southee to Smith, 1 run, short and wide outside off, Smith cuts it gently to deep point. Didn't come down hard at it and just rolled the wrists to hit it along the turf

93.6   Boult to Burns, FOUR, skims off the thick outside edge and dribbles away past a diving gully. It's a real soul-shatterer for the bowler seeing the edges going straight to ground. Draws Burns into a loose drive away from the body and sees him collect a streaky boundary

93.5   Boult to Burns, no run, slightly late to defend this short of length delivery and ends up chopping it on the popping crease. Burns seemed concerned that it might roll back and moved across to provide an obstruction in its path
93.4   Boult to Burns, no run, fullish outside off, pushed to cover
93.3   Boult to Smith, 1 run, stands tall to get on top of the bounce and then rolls his wrists on the ball to escort it to fine leg
93.2   Boult to Smith, 2 runs, the line is off and middle stump, which is too straight for someone like Smith, as he simply shuffles across and tucks it behind square before haring back for a couple
93.1   Boult to Smith, no run, back of a length delivery which is softly nudged into the on-side
Strange how quickly all the movement with this new ball has vaporized. Can't see how New Zealand can break through here. And to think that they still have to pick 8 more wickets. Scary thought
92.6   Southee to Burns, no run, keeps it in the corridor just outside off, Burns shoulders arms
92.5   Southee to Burns, no run, calmly stays on the back foot and offers a dead-bat
92.4   Southee to Burns, no run, presses forward and pushes it on the up to cover
92.3   Southee to Smith, 1 run, short of length outside off, steered towards third man
92.2   Southee to Smith, no run, gentle ball reading 127ks on the speed gun, Smith slid back and turned it to mid-wicket
92.1   Southee to Smith, no run, hops across and blocks a short of length delivery to cover
Tim Southee [19.0-4-59-0] is back into the attack

Drinks are on the field now. Smith followed in Burns' footsteps by notching up his 14th Test ton. The two have certainly put Australia in control of the proceedings. Henry got a few to jag off the seam with the second new ball. However, New Zealand look largely flat at the moment.

91.6   Boult to Burns, 2 runs, fuller length delivery and just outside off, Burns blazes the drive and pierces the gap through cover. Eventually, the fielder at deep backward point runs to his right and keeps Burns to just a couple of runs
91.5   Boult to Burns, no run, length ball and in that zone outside off, Burns covers his off-pole and leaves it alone
91.4   Boult to Burns, no run, angled away from the right-hander, Burns is not interested in playing at it
91.3   Boult to Burns, no run, good length delivery and outside off, Burns opens the face ever so slightly and defends it to backward point
91.2   Boult to Burns, no run, fullish and slanting across the right-hander, Burns shoulders arms
91.1   Boult to Burns, 2 runs, Boult offers a touch of width, Burns punches it to sweeper cover. Good running between the wickets allow the duo to pinch a couple
90.6   Matt Henry to Smith, no run, low full toss from Henry, Smith bunts it down to mid-on
90.5   Matt Henry to Burns, 1 run, width on offer, Burns punches it to deep backward point, who swoops down on the ball quickly and keeps the batsman to just a single
90.4   Matt Henry to Smith, 1 run, too straight from Henry, Smith helps it around the corner to deep mid-wicket

90.3   Matt Henry to Smith, FOUR, sliding down leg, Smith whips it firmly and all along the carpet to the mid-wicket fence. Anderson from mid-wicket looks to hunt it down, and puts in a dive, but to no avail. He even crashed into the ad-cushions. However, no harm done
90.2   Matt Henry to Smith, no run, fuller length delivery and in that one square foot window outside off, Smith is not interested in playing at it

89.5   Boult to Smith, 3 runs, fuller length delivery and outside off, Smith leans into the drive and it runs away towards the deep extra cover fence. The fielder at cover hounds it down, but can't prevent the pair from nabbing three more runs to the bag

89.3   Boult to Smith, no run, Boult bowls it closer to the off-stump, Smith shoulders arms
89.2   Boult to Smith, no run, good length delivery and outside off, Smith ignores

89.1   Boult to Smith, FOUR, Smith is a run-machine. He composes his 14th Test ton. This is also his 6th century as a captain. On expected lines, he raises his bat to acknowledge his teammates and the crowd. It was a fuller length delivery that was bowled outside off, Smith drove it to the square third man boundary. It was in the air for a while, but the gully fielder had no chance of pouching that one
Trent Boult [19.0-5-58-2] is back into the attack
88.6   Matt Henry to Burns, FOUR, Henry ushers in a bumper, but Burns rocks back quickly and nails the pull to the deep backward square leg fence. It crashed into the ad-cushions
88.5   Matt Henry to Burns, 2 runs, very full and on off-stump, Joe squeezes it out to extra cover. Now, couple more runs added to the tally
88.4   Matt Henry to Burns, no run, fuller length delivery and in that zone outside off, left alone to the keeper. This is probing stuff from Henry
88.3   Matt Henry to Burns, no run, Henry again slants it into the right-hander, Burns is squared up in his defence. However, he is still able to keep it out
88.2   Matt Henry to Burns, no run, short of a length delivery that comes back into the right-hander, Burns meets it out with a textbook forward defence
88.1   Matt Henry to Burns, no run, good length delivery and in that channel outside off, Burns shoulders arms
87.6   Corey Anderson to Smith, no run, there and thereabouts outside off, Smith leaves it untouched
87.5   Corey Anderson to Smith, no run, fuller length delivery and zooming in on the stumps, Smith clips it to mid-on

87.2   Corey Anderson to Burns, 1 run, too straight from Anderson, Burns tucks it to mid-wicket for an easy single. It brings Smith on strike. He is on 99

86.5   Matt Henry to Smith, no run, the slip cordon dish out an appeal for caught behind. However, nothing from the bowler. Finally, they decide to not go for the review. On replays it is clear that it hit the back leg on its way to the keeper. Good length delivery that nips away from the right-hander, Smith is opened up in his defence and it hits his back pad on its way to the keeper

86.3   Matt Henry to Smith, no run, back of a length delivery that slants in, Smith defends it to mid-on

86.2   Matt Henry to Smith, 2 runs, short of length delivery and outside off, Smith rides on the bounce and punches it. It pockets in the gap between cover and backward point. Eventually, the fielder at backward point hunts it down, but the pair nab a couple of runs
86.1   Matt Henry to Smith, no run, back of a length delivery and angled in, Smith shuffles across and keeps it out
85.6   Corey Anderson to Burns, no run, fuller length delivery and just outside off, Burns takes a baby step forward to defend
85.5   Corey Anderson to Burns, no run, too wide of off to elicit a stroke

84.4   Matt Henry to Smith, no run, good length delivery that nips back into the right-hander, Smith lets it go by
84.3   Matt Henry to Smith, no run, Smith takes it from the stumps and clips it to mid-wicket
84.2   Matt Henry to Smith, no run, fuller length delivery and on the stumps, Smith drives it back towards the bowler
84.1   Matt Henry to Smith, no run, good length delivery and outside off, Smith greets it with a lifted bat

83.4   Boult to Burns, no run, fullish and outside off, left alone to the keeper

83.3   Boult to Burns, leg byes, 2 runs, too straight from Boult, Burns looks to clip it to fine leg and misses. But good running between the wickets help the pair to add two leg-byes to the team. Now, the stand is worth 200 runs
83.2   Boult to Burns, no run, slanting across the right-hander, Burns lets it go by

83.1   Boult to Smith, 3 runs, very full and on the stumps, Smith drives it straight down the ground. Anderson from mid-on hunts it down and slides to save a run for his team. The TV umpire comes into play to see whether he has made a clean stop. Anderson looks fine and as a result, one run has been saved

82.6   Matt Henry to Burns, no run, well, Burns can count himself lucky. In fact, the extra bounce saved Burns there. Henry gets it to snake back into the right-hander, Burns leaves it untouched. However, it missed the off-stump by a kitten's whisker

81.5   Boult to Smith, FOUR, speared down leg, Smith neatly clips it to the fine leg boundary. Smith is very strong in that area. Poor bowling from Boult though. On a good note, that ball swung for Boult
81.4   Boult to Smith, no run, curling back a touch, defended
81.3   Boult to Smith, no run, fuller this time, pushed back down the pitch
81.2   Boult to Smith, no run, length ball around off, blocked
81.1   Boult to Smith, no run, length delivery and just outside off, defended off the back foot
Trent Boult [17.0-5-47-2] is back into the attack
80.6   Matt Henry to Burns, no run, good length delivery and just outside off, defended towards backward point

80.5   Matt Henry to Burns, leg byes, FOUR, this one nips back into the right-hander, but Henry gets his line wrong as he splays it down leg, Burns misses out with his clip. It hits his thigh pad and scurries to the fine leg fence for four leg-byes

80.1   Matt Henry to Burns, no run, and Henry starts with a ripper of a delivery. It seemed like a fast leg-break. Henry got it to jag away off the seam appreciably, Burns is opened up in his back foot defence and is beaten on the outside edge

The second new ball is due and it has been taken. Interestingly, Henry has the new cherry in his hand

78.1   Wagner to Smith, 1 run, shortish delivery and angling away from the right-hander, Smith pulls it to fine leg

Going into the final session, Australia hold all the aces. Smith and Burns have looked largely untroubled on a track that has flattened out considerably. New Zealand need an inspired performance from someone in the camp to make a comeback. Remember, in another three overs, the second new ball will be available.

Another session which Australia will claim as theirs. Burns and Smith ensured that the wickets column remained undisturbed with a very solid batting display. Burns even went on to compile his 3rd Test ton, one which has been underpinned by grit and determination. On the other hand, Smith has erected a wall at his end, with nothing going past him. To be fair to the Kiwis, not a lot has happened off the deck. Something to look forward to for them will be the second new ball which will become available early after the break. Need to dig deep..

Welcome back! Burns and Smith played with pluck and steel to help Australia whittle away at New Zealand's lead. Can the able duo continue their good work? Or will New Zealand's pacers bowl with purpose to make further dents in the batting line-up? Boult will open the proceedings after lunch...

A session which started promisingly for the hosts, faded off in the second hour of play as the duo of Burns and Smith started to get the run-flow going. There was lots of speculation as to how the pitch would behave today. Whether there will be anywhere near enough help like on the morning of Day 1? But no. The sideways movement has dissipated. There was a little up front which Boult exploited to nip off Khawaja. It was followed by a good intense battle between bat and ball. However, the Kiwi bowlers got a bit too impatient after the drinks break deviating from the good length area to offer a barrage of half-volleys. That evaporated all the pressure which had been built early on and allowed this pair to seize the upper hand. Looks like a long day's toil ahead as this pitch will only get better and better.

The players are out in the middle. It is bright and sunny at the moment in Christchurch. Southee has the red cherry in his hand. He has 3 slips and a gully in place.

For Australia, the pace troika of Pattinson, Bird and Hazlewood took two wickets apiece. Nathan Lyon picked up three scalps. New Zealand's spearhead, Trent Boult then prised out David Warner at the fag end of the day. The hosts would look to make further inroads, especially in the first session of Day 2 before the moisture dries out. Stay tuned! Australia will resume their innings shortly.

Day 2: Hello and welcome to our coverage of the second Test between Australia and New Zealand. The highlight of Day 1 was Brendon McCullum belting out the quickest Test century in just 54 balls. He unleashed a stream of fours and sixes to harvest a sparkling hundred and help his team recover. McCullum rode his luck, as he was dismissed by Pattinson off a no-ball. However, it has to be said that none of the Australian bowlers were able to curb him for long. Corey Anderson, too, cracked an eye-wateringly imposing fifty.

Brendon McCullum's whirlwind hundred ensured that New Zealand posted a competitive total on the board. In fact, McCullum also registered the quickest Test ton, which came in a mere 54 balls. Corey Anderson too played his part with a vital fifty. Trent Boult then sent Warner back to the pavilion to give the hosts a slight edge. Earlier, Australia's seamers landed crucial blows to put the tourists in the ascendancy. However, the turning point of the day came when Pattinson dismissed McCullum off a no-ball. Once he got the reprieve, New Zealand's skipper played with a dash of fearlessness and cracked a blistering century. Join us tomorrow for the second day's play. Until then, goodbye.

A boundary laden first innings from New Zealand. They were down and out for all count when skipper, Brendon McCullum, playing in his 101st and last Test walked on. He made a name for himself with his bold and aggressive batting. It doesn't come off everytime, but when it does, it's awe-inspiring. Australia didn't know what hit them as fours and sixes were clubbed with ease. He found a willing partner in Corey Anderson and the pair added 179 runs from just 112 balls. McCullum also recorded the fastest ever Test ton - off just 54 deliveries, beating the previous record of 56 - jointly held by Sir Viv Richards and Misbah-ul-Haq. What a way to go. Inspired by his aggression, the later New Zealand batsmen adopted the same strategy, BJ Watling helped himself to a 57-ball 58 and the hosts finished with 370 on the board. The pitch is still helping the pacers and the New Zealand bowlers will fancy their chances. Join us in a while..

McCullum and Anderson smacked the opposition ranks to all corners of the ground to help the home team recover after they were in a spot of bother. Most of the time, it was raining fours and sixes from McCullum's bat. A dot ball seemed more like an oasis in desert. McCullum even went on to notch up the fastest hundred in Tests. His splendid ton came off just 54 balls. On the other hand, Anderson, too, gave a fine exhibition of power-hitting and cracked a handy fifty. Australia would rue the fact that McCullum was caught by M Marsh off Pattinson at gully, but it turned out to be a no-ball. It has to be said though, the visitors would be pleased that both the set batsmen have been dismissed before tea. Join us in a few minutes for the final session...

49.6   Bird to Watling, no run, length delivery and on the stumps, Watling turns it into the on-side. Phew, that is tea then. Now, 199 runs were added in this session. It gives an inkling as to the kind of power-hitting that one saw from McCullum and Anderson.

The fans who came to watch McCullum bat in his final Test have certainly got their money's worth. On expected lines, he gets a standing ovation while making his way back to the hut. They are changing the ball now. No wonder. The beating it has taken today. Phew! Okay, so drinks have been called for as well. I'm out of breath, and words to describe this bloke. It was just scripted. Somewhere in the heavens, to end this way. Pattinson must be remembering that no-ball. Has a no-ball ever cost so much, ever? This match has turned around dramatically. Ha, even the word dramatic sounds like an understatement

The Lunch has gone down and probably rumbled on it's way through everyone's tummies in anticipation of what this second session holds..

Despite losing the openers and Nicholls, New Zealand find themselves in a decent position at lunch. On a track that darted around, the Aussie pacers explored every nook and cranny of the batsmen's defence. However, the credit has to go to Williamson for twinning steadfast defence with measured judgment outside the off-stump to keep the opposition at bay. At the other end, Brendon McCullum, playing in his final Test, unfurled a series of eye-catching shots and looked in ominous touch. Hazlewood was the best bowler on show for the tourists and was rewarded with the scalp of Nicholls. Join us in a while for the post-lunch session....

2.1   Hazlewood to Latham, no run, drifting across off stump on a good length, Latham is fairly sure about his sticks and holds the bat aloft to leave

James Pattinson, right-arm fast, comes into the attack

Guptill and Latham are at the crease. Guptill is on strike. Hazlewood will open the attack
Guptill and Latham walk out under a bright sun. Ah, the sweet sight of pristine whites. Here's Hazlewood..

Baz: It would have been nice to win the toss but our batsmen now have to do a job. Had the privilege to lead for a couple of years so hope to cap off now. A couple of changes in the form of Wagner and Henry coming in. There is grass, live grass here.
Smith: We're going to bowl. Looks to be some moisture in the wicket and some grass. Hopefully our bowlers go well here. Pattinson comes in for Siddle.
We have live pictures from the Hagley Oval now which show the grass banks brimming with people.

All the rage going around is how fitting it is for Baz not to win his final toss. His record is shambolic with those, winning a mere 12 out of 31. Nonetheless, here is New Zealand's big test. To be facing the worst batting conditions against a brand new cherry which will be darting around early morning.
Teams:
New Zealand (Playing XI): Martin Guptill, Tom Latham, Kane Williamson, Henry Nicholls, Brendon McCullum(c), Corey Anderson, BJ Watling(w), Matt Henry, Tim Southee, Neil Wagner, Trent Boult
Australia (Playing XI): Joe Burns, David Warner, Usman Khawaja, Steven Smith(c), Adam Voges, Mitchell Marsh, Peter Nevill(w), James Pattinson, Josh Hazlewood, Nathan Lyon, Jackson Bird

On expected lines, New Zealand have gone in for an all-pace attack here, choosing Neil Wagner over Mark Craig. The other change is in the form of Matt Henry coming in for the injured Doug Bracewell. For Australia, the only change is Pattinson for Siddle.
Australia have won the toss and have opted to field

There are a few team changes beckoning owing to injury. Peter Siddle pulled up with back spasms at Wellington which were enough to rule him out of this one. James Pattinson is fit and bowling well in the nets, in the words of skipper Steven Smith so he will be drafted in most likely. New Zealand have a man down as well from the Basin Reserve. Doug Bracewell appeared to have done some mischief to his shoulder, which dovetails him to the injured list of Ross Taylor and Mitchell Santner. However, no replacement has been called upon as the Kiwis already possess Matt Henry and Neil Wagner in their squad. Expect the former to be in the XI with his added pace.

Okay right. We have a Test match on our hands. After Australia ran away with the first one, it has got them to the threshold of a rare away series win in recent times. A win which will also see them clinch the much-prized Test Championship Mace. All they need is a draw. But they are the Aussies. They don't think that way. And a draw is highly unlikely given the nature of the pitch here.

As a cricket fan, all I feel today is an overwhelming emotion of gratitude. I am grateful. Grateful for all the times Baz put his body on the line near the ropes to save a meagre run. Grateful for his breakneck and sometimes reckless batting. Grateful for all those moments of exhilararation which were palpable when a bowler stood at the top of his mark not knowing what is about to happen. Just grateful.

08:30 Local Time, 20:30 GMT, 02:00 IST: Hear them? Listen carefully. The chimes of destruction. Impending doom. Every time a bowler stood at the top of his mark to bowl to Brendon McCullum, he could hear it. And now they are fading. Fading as we prepare to embark on McCullum's swansong. Well, for all we know, he might just come out and make those metals explode and dash off into the sunset. In what will be his 101st consecutive Test since debut, and final one, New Zealand seek retribution and parity to deny Australia the No. 1 Test ranking. So let's hold onto our seats and witness the majesty of Baz entering his final sprint, as will the packed house at Hagley Oval.
Teams:

Australia (From): David Warner, Joe Burns, Usman Khawaja, Steven Smith(c), Adam Voges, Mitchell Marsh, Peter Nevill(w), James Pattinson, Josh Hazlewood, Nathan Lyon, Jackson Bird, Shaun Marsh, Chadd Sayers

New Zealand (From): Martin Guptill, Tom Latham, Kane Williamson, Henry Nicholls, Brendon McCullum(c), Corey Anderson, BJ Watling(w), Tim Southee, Matt Henry, Neil Wagner, Trent Boult, Mark Craig, Luke Ronchi
